The Portsmouth Livery Company versus Simeon Watson and Another. The powers of corporations to sue a personal action are not restricted to corporations created by the laws of this commonwealth. To this action of trover the defendants pleaded, in abatement 01 the writ and declaration, “ that the Portsmouth Livery Company is not a body incorporated by the legislature of this commonwealth, or under any law enacted by said legislature, or any authority of said commonwealth, and are not, by the laws of this commonwealth, authorized to sue this action, in and by the said name of the Portsmouth Livery Company, in manner and form as they have declared in the action aforesaid ; and the said defendants further say, that if the damages demanded in this action are by law recoverable in any form of action the same should have been demanded in an action of the case commenced by and in the name of all the persons constituting the said Portsmouth Livery Company, suing jointly in their private and individual capacities, according to the laws of said commonwealth.” To this plea the plaintiffs replied by a general demurrer, which was joined by the defendants. Mellen, of counsel for the defendants,

being called on by the Court to support the plea, contended that a corporation was entirely indebted to the law for its existence; and this corporation, not having been created by our law, can have no legal existence here. Mellen also referred to some observations of the Chief Justice in delivering the opinion of the Court, in the case of Pearsall Al. vs. Dwight. (1)

Whitman, for the plaintiffs,

contended that the plea was predicated on no legal principles, and was perfectly novel.

* In the case of The President, &c., of the Union Turnpike [ * 92 ] vs. Jenkins and Trustees, (2) this objection to the capacity *104of the plaintiffs lay, if it lies in the case at bar; and yet it was not thought of'by the very able counsel for the defendant in that cause.

2 Mass. Rep. 88, 89.

 Per Curiam,.

The principle suggested by the plea in this case, as a rule of law, respecting societies not incorporated by some statute of this commonwealth, that the members are to sue in their private capacities and names, as individuals and copartners, has no foundation in any maxim, or in any argument of public convenience or policy, or in any positive provision of any statute. Our legislature recognize, in many instances, and to many purposes, corporations existing by foreign laws ; particularly those created by laws of any of the United States, as in the statutes against forgery and counterfeiting; and other instances might be mentioned.

Corporations are artificial persons, and their existence and rights are to be proved, whether the result of a public or private statute, domestic or foreign, as any other fact of that nature is to be proved. Of public corporations within this commonwealth, whether sole or aggregate, the Court are judicially informed, as they are of all other public statutes ; and as to private corporations, and those, whether public or private, which exist by the laws of any other state, or within any foreign jurisdiction, these are to be proved, and satisfactory evidence will be required, as of any other fact material in an issue to the country. But the powers of corporations to sue a personal action within this state are not restricted to corporations created by the laws of this commonwealth, as supposed by this plea in abatement, which is adjudged bad and insufficient. (1)

Respondeos ouster awarded.

ADDITIONAL NOTE.

TA foreign corporation cannot be sued in Massachusetts. — Peckham vs. North, &c., 16 Pick. 274.

In an action upon a joint contract, made by such corporation and an individual, it seems, the former need not be named in the writ.—Ibid.

In Pennsylvania, a foreign corporation cannot be summoned by a service on its head or chief officer, who happens to be at the time within the territorial jurisdiction of the court. — Nash vs. The Rector, Sec., 1 Miles, 78.

In Connecticut, a foreign corporation, a part of whose stockholders reside there, is not liable to be sued by writ of summons in the courts of that state.—Middlebrook vs. The Springfield, Sec., 14 Conn. 301.
